Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The Carbondale Study: A Model for Student and Community Engagement in Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The traditional model of academic work is built on three pillars: 1) active production of new research on scientific and creative work, 2) diffusion of disciplinary knowledge through teaching, and 3) active engagement with and service to public audiences. Nevertheless, universities and colleges are criticized for supporting academic "silos" and "ivory towers" that prevent blending these three pillars into coherent, impactful programs. This project introduces a practical model into political science for combining research, pedagogical, and service missions into a single project. Our model draws on three basic principles. First, the project is intentionally interdisciplinary in order to break "silos" of departments and to draw on the insight of multiple disciplines in policy-relevant research. Second, students are explicitly included in the project through class enrollment that requires participation in data collection and analysis, both to enlighten pedagogical material and acquire practical skills. Finally, the research topic is grounded in local issues that are of interest to citizens and stakeholders. It is specifically focused on concerns that are on the local agenda, providing new information about public opinion into
the debate.

Two research questions provide the substantive and methodological anchor of this project: What is the impact of local stakeholders and citizens in local policy issues? And, what do these impacts tell us about broader policy processes? Our research design calls for collection of data on 1) the network of local stakeholders and 2) a random sample of local citizens. The data will be used to understand how horizontal power (connections among stakeholders, connections among citizens) and vertical power (connects between citizens and elites) relates to policy discussion. We will examine how these connections operate in the context of five policy areas of interest to the community: economic development, race and pollution, crime and policing, access to health care, and town-gown relations. Students will gather data via in-person survey; local policy-makers will be consulted on the survey to ensure relevance to the community. The project will have deliverables that include academic publishing, presentations to local organizations, and student theses and dissertations. This project will gather a unique data set on how social connections intersect with individual traits to produce attitudes on local policy issues. This data will yield systematic measures of social networks of stakeholders and citizens, as well as links between the two groups. Such measures allow us to examine the representation of both groups in policy debates, as well as the underlying impact of social structure on amplifying or muting particular voices in policy discussion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The traditional model of academic work is built on three pillars: 1) active production of new research on scientific and creative work, 2) diffusion of disciplinary knowledge through teaching, and 3) active engagement with and service to public audiences.  Nevertheless, universities and colleges are criticized for supporting academic “silos” and “ivory towers” that prevent blending these three pillars into coherent, impactful programs. The goal of this project is to combine these three pillars into one project. There are two outcomes to date.: 1) students and faculty work together on a survey that focused on local issues, 2) Faculty and graduate students collected data from three other surveys, each that examined a different part of the local  small city. 

The most important activities revolve on data collection and analysis, mainly focusing on the data of the city actors and stakeholders.This part of our research is ongoing. To the extent that we have understanding our data there are important differences between our three data sources (the community members, city workers, and stakeholders). As noted above we have information that helps us understand the relationships of the members of the community, the city workers, and the stakeholders. We also have information about crime, race, money use in the city, and the relationship between the city and university. Although not all of these data sources have the same information about these topics, there is a notable overlap. Generally, our findings suggest that our three actors are very similar. Although there are some differences, and believe that there are notable differences, most of our data suggests that the three groups are more cohesive than you would think. 

The other main outcome has been used to use students in our research. Our first survey used 15 students to learn about our case of a small city. The most important of this outcome has been to learn the use of surveys, something that can be used in future jobs and politics, journalism, etc. Importantly, our students also learned skills such as collaboration, city saftey, and comparing different types of problems in small towns. Related to this some of the researchers have created a potential class for honor students. It will focus on basic theroies of small communities, their local community, and understanding the role of how small towns operate on policy issues.
